description: Word 2016 Expert for Mac takes users to the next level in document processing.  This series explores how to enhance long documents with episodes that include: creating a table of contents, generating an index, adding footnotes and endnotes, inserting bookmarks and cross references, labeling figures with captions, and citing references for a bibliography. Also covered in long documents is how to create a master document and add sub documents for large projects. Other topics in this series include how to collaborate in Word and through Office 365 online, secure your documents, and add or edit document properties. While Word 2016 Expert for Mac is a continuation from the Word 2016 Advanced and Essentials for Mac series, episodes can be viewed individually for specific topics or enjoyed in sequence.

Also covered in long documents is how to create a master document and add sub documents for large projects. Other topics in this series include how to collaborate in Word and through Office 365 online, secure your documents, and add or edit document properties. While Word 2016 Expert for Mac is a continuation from the Word 2016 Advanced and Essentials for Mac series, episodes can be viewed individually for specific topics or enjoyed in sequence.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne demonstrate and explain using bookmarks and cross references. Here they show you bookmark specifics like marking a location, naming conventions, and selecting a range of content. Then they look at cross reference specifics like using hyperlinks and choosing what text to display as the cross reference.
episodes.title: Bookmarks and Cross References

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne show you how to insert a table of contents (TOC) into your Word documents. Here they will go over heading levels (styles), TOC templates, map to custom styles for TOC, updating TOC, and removing TOC.
episodes.title: Table of Contents

episodes.description: Vonne and Daniel show how to manually mark words and ranges to be included in an index and then how generate the index. They also cover how to auto mark entries from a concordance file, how to update and format an index, and how to remove marked entries.
episodes.title: Index

episodes.description: Citing work for use in research or academic papers is very important. In this episode, Vonne and Ronnie show you how easy Word has made it to add and manage sources, insert citations, and generate and update a bibliography.
episodes.title: Citations and Bibliography

And that's the neat thing about

References and

Yes, it also referred to it as references.

It is an important part of these

Having those citations ready to go,

00:21:06.240 --> 00:21:09.050
But that ends it for

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne discuss footnotes and endnotes. They cover how to add, format, update, delete, and convert footnotes and/or endnotes in a Word document.
episodes.title: Footnotes and Endnotes

So Vonne, in terms of Word, this actually

Right there, not up, up, up.

Endnotes go to the end of either

That might be a little easier to kind of,

But that would be the whole

It's usually something like you

00:05:40.080 --> 00:05:41.070
>> Right.
>> Right?

And you have that and then there's

which we actually talked about in

112
00:05:51.178 --> 00:05:53.880
So there's different
reasons why you may or

113
00:05:53.880 --> 00:05:57.850

114
00:05:57.850 --> 00:06:01.960
I do have a little article in

00:06:01.960 --> 00:06:06.550

116

But it's really more of like it, more

117
00:06:11.329 --> 00:06:16.478
Advantages and disadvantages,
they're closer, so it's a little easier.

118
00:06:16.478 --> 00:06:21.328
Disadvantage is if you have a lot,
it might be a little cluttering.

119
00:06:21.328 --> 00:06:23.650
Advantages for

120

go all the way to the back of the book.

121

Those are kinda the whys.

And it's really just, hey,
if you're gonna use them,

and then, as with anything,

00:06:40.480 --> 00:06:43.608
Great, nice little tidbits

And the other thing I have in here

129

[LAUGH] All right, I love this and this
where, hey, if we where typing this out on

131
00:07:02.768 --> 00:07:05.765

past that need to change?

132
00:07:05.765 --> 00:07:07.469
[SOUND] Nightmare if you're doing it

133
00:07:07.469 --> 00:07:08.103

>> [LAUGH]

134
00:07:08.103 --> 00:07:11.265
>> Super easy if you're doing it in Word.

135
00:07:11.265 --> 00:07:12.517
Love it, awesome.

Now with these, we saw that there was that
preview when I hovered over the reference

and I was trying to remember, right here,
see either question there's that

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Ronnie demonstrate adding captions to graphical elements. They cover how to create custom labels, how to insert or delete captions that should automatically update (and how to force them to update when it doesn’t auto update), and ultimately generate a table of figures.
episodes.title: Captions and Table of Figures

episodes.description: Vonne and Ronnie demonstrate how to create a master document and use the Outlining tab on the Ribbon. They show how to add, collapse and expand, and unlink subdocuments. They also discuss the importance of using consistent headings.
episodes.title: Master Document

And not have to keep
doing multiple copies and

267
00:14:55.730 --> 00:14:59.980
paste like that poor woman had to
do that one time in your example.

268
00:14:59.980 --> 00:15:02.160
And it acts just like a regular document,
there's nothing wrong.

269
00:15:02.160 --> 00:15:06.450
And this is where if you had multiple
subdocuments, let's go back and

270
00:15:06.450 --> 00:15:08.650
add another one just to have some fun.

271
00:15:08.650 --> 00:15:11.730
We'll go back to View,
we'll go back to Outline,

272
00:15:11.730 --> 00:15:14.960
I will show the Document button because
that's where I need to insert it, but

273
00:15:14.960 --> 00:15:18.240
you have to still think, where do I
want to insert the next document?

274
00:15:18.240 --> 00:15:20.160
You're gonna scroll down and

275
00:15:20.160 --> 00:15:24.080
make sure your cursor is in
the place where you want to be.

276
00:15:24.080 --> 00:15:27.580
So then you will Insert,
come out to our desktop and

277
00:15:27.580 --> 00:15:31.240
we will go with the,
let's go with the Queen of Hearts.

278
00:15:31.240 --> 00:15:33.150
And there's the next one,
we'll do one more.

279
00:15:33.150 --> 00:15:35.720
Cursor is where I want it to be, Insert,

280
00:15:35.720 --> 00:15:39.230
and then where are we?
>> Knights.

281
00:15:39.230 --> 00:15:40.490
>> The Knights, thank you.

282
00:15:40.490 --> 00:15:44.907
So now I have our three subdocuments,
they'er all there.

283
00:15:44.907 --> 00:15:49.883
I can collapse the subdocuments, but then
I'm gonna have to expand them anyways to

284
00:15:49.883 --> 00:15:54.525
make them look the right way, cuz if I
close this it's gonna look like links.

285
00:15:54.525 --> 00:15:59.136
So you gotta keep them
expanded to see the text in

286
00:15:59.136 --> 00:16:02.840
its normal capacity in print layout.

287
00:16:02.840 --> 00:16:05.468
So let's expand it, let's close it.

288
00:16:05.468 --> 00:16:06.404
There we go.

289
00:16:06.404 --> 00:16:08.870
And this is just one big old document.

290
00:16:08.870 --> 00:16:14.100
And this is the same thing like if I
wanted to create a table of contents.

291
00:16:14.100 --> 00:16:14.838
I could do that, right?

292
00:16:14.838 --> 00:16:18.095
Because all it's doing is pulling
the heading, totally fine.

293
00:16:18.095 --> 00:16:23.140
If I had each sub-document already
marked with index entries, I could

294
00:16:23.140 --> 00:16:28.896
then generate an index in the master
document pulling from the sub-documents.

295
00:16:28.896 --> 00:16:33.770
Again, it's special but
it's still just a regular document.

296
00:16:33.770 --> 00:16:38.360
It's just how the text kinda got in there,
but it's still just text.

297
00:16:38.360 --> 00:16:40.970
I think that's the thing
that throws people off.

298
00:16:40.970 --> 00:16:42.830
Treat it normally.

299
00:16:42.830 --> 00:16:45.750
It's all good, it's fine.

300
00:16:45.750 --> 00:16:49.710
It's just that kinda weird
views that you have to do,

301
00:16:49.710 --> 00:16:51.650
and the linking.
>> All right, so

302
00:16:51.650 --> 00:16:54.170
Vonne, let's say that we
create this sub document.

303
00:16:54.170 --> 00:16:55.780
And just like the example
that I was using,

304
00:16:55.780 --> 00:16:58.330
one of the worst things that
this lady had to deal with and

305
00:16:58.330 --> 00:17:02.720
why she chose to merge it all into one
document, was the idea of page numbers.

306
00:17:02.720 --> 00:17:06.557
Will this, if we tell them don't put page
numbers, can we actually use a master

307
00:17:06.557 --> 00:17:10.532
document and put page numbers and actually
have them all do what we want them to do?

308
00:17:10.532 --> 00:17:13.817
>> Yeah, if I go right into here and

309
00:17:13.817 --> 00:17:21.264
we go into insert and we go with a page
number, and we'll go with center.

310
00:17:21.264 --> 00:17:23.820
And we'll click OK, and there you go.

311
00:17:23.820 --> 00:17:26.930
They're just straight up
regular page numbers.

312
00:17:26.930 --> 00:17:27.630
Everything goes.

313
00:17:27.630 --> 00:17:30.060
And then if you added
more in a sub-document,

314
00:17:30.060 --> 00:17:34.590
say somebody, I found a whole other
passage that I wanted to, it's all there.

315
00:17:34.590 --> 00:17:38.550
And the nice thing is you don't
really have to force the updates,

316
00:17:38.550 --> 00:17:40.270
like in a field like we had.

317
00:17:40.270 --> 00:17:42.050
As long as the files are all saved.

318
00:17:42.050 --> 00:17:44.590
Now if you start moving things around,
>> [LAUGH]

319
00:17:44.590 --> 00:17:46.595
>> Then it's gonna get all wonky, so

320
00:17:46.595 --> 00:17:47.148
be very,

321
00:17:47.148 --> 00:17:51.910
very careful about it because it is
creating a path to that particular file.

322
00:17:51.910 --> 00:17:53.948
Don't rename it, don't move it.

323
00:17:53.948 --> 00:17:57.666
You're gonna have problems if you do,
and then it's like [SOUND].

324
00:17:57.666 --> 00:18:01.140
But the other nice thing is,
you saw how easy that was.

325
00:18:01.140 --> 00:18:05.795
If you really get all out of sorts,
go ahead and find them,

326
00:18:05.795 --> 00:18:09.120
start a new file,
[SOUND] pop them all in and

327
00:18:09.120 --> 00:18:12.260
then kind of start from scratch.
>> All right.

328
00:18:12.260 --> 00:18:13.870
>> So that's something to always

329
00:18:13.870 --> 00:18:14.390
think about.

330
00:18:14.390 --> 00:18:18.560
It's not too tirely hard or
a long process to

331
00:18:18.560 --> 00:18:21.430
create a master document.
>> All right Vonne, now that we have

332
00:18:21.430 --> 00:18:24.990
those page numbers, you also mentioned
the idea that they're linked, and

333
00:18:24.990 --> 00:18:28.100
usually they're linked because we really
want people to be able to edit them and

334
00:18:28.100 --> 00:18:30.020
that kind of shows up
the way they want to.

335
00:18:30.020 --> 00:18:32.870
But what if everything is done and
over with, and

336
00:18:32.870 --> 00:18:36.790
now we want to be able to kind of
remove that, is that possible?

337
00:18:36.790 --> 00:18:39.220
And that way we don't affect
those other documents anymore?

338
00:18:39.220 --> 00:18:41.390
>> Unconnecting the sub documents from

339
00:18:41.390 --> 00:18:42.620
the master document?
>> Right.

340
00:18:42.620 --> 00:18:44.470
>> You can, yes you can unlink them.

341
00:18:44.470 --> 00:18:48.415
And maybe cuz you're, maybe somebody's
done with the editing or they're doing

342
00:18:48.415 --> 00:18:51.973
too much editing for what you need and
you need to cut them off or whatever.

343
00:18:51.973 --> 00:18:56.642
So there's multiple reasons of why
you want to not have links to them.

344
00:18:56.642 --> 00:18:59.864
It's not too hard, so why don't we
go ahead and come back down and

345
00:18:59.864 --> 00:19:01.400
go back into our outline view.

346
00:19:01.400 --> 00:19:04.380
So we need to go to view and outline.

347
00:19:04.380 --> 00:19:08.220
And we can go ahead and show the document.

348
00:19:08.220 --> 00:19:12.590
And then right there,
right underneath insert, there's unlink.

349
00:19:12.590 --> 00:19:18.290
So if I'm here, with my cursor within that
subdocument, and then I click unlink,

350
00:19:18.290 --> 00:19:20.610
notice like the box goes away?
>> Yeah.

351
00:19:20.610 --> 00:19:22.810
>> Yeah, and once the box goes away,

352
00:19:22.810 --> 00:19:25.595
now we're just in regular outline mode.

353
00:19:25.595 --> 00:19:28.430
It has nothing to do with a subdocument.
>> So

354
00:19:28.430 --> 00:19:32.820
this is now just a copy of the original
document and it is no longer linked.

355
00:19:32.820 --> 00:19:34.560
So we don't have to worry
about somebody editing and

356
00:19:34.560 --> 00:19:36.490
affecting my master document?
>> Correct.

357
00:19:36.490 --> 00:19:40.720
If I made changes to this in the master
document, not effect to the sub or

358
00:19:40.720 --> 00:19:41.820
vice versa.

359
00:19:41.820 --> 00:19:45.780
So if I wanted to unlink all of them,
I just get back down into the second one,

360
00:19:45.780 --> 00:19:48.470
go ahead and unlink, come down into here,

361
00:19:48.470 --> 00:19:52.750
we can unlink and
then this is just a regular file.

362
00:19:52.750 --> 00:19:57.040
No anything going on, I can take
out the page breaks and everything.

363
00:19:57.040 --> 00:20:00.450
So that's also maybe like an easy
way to almost like copying and

364
00:20:00.450 --> 00:20:01.830
pasting, right?
>> Right.

365
00:20:01.830 --> 00:20:03.440
>> Bring them all in,

366
00:20:03.440 --> 00:20:07.510
do the master document, then unlink
them and then do what you need to do.

367
00:20:09.250 --> 00:20:10.680
That just came to me right now [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

368
00:20:10.680 --> 00:20:13.497
>> So I was like that's pretty smart.

369
00:20:13.497 --> 00:20:15.578
So yeah, master documents,

370
00:20:15.578 --> 00:20:21.327
not too terribly hard if everything goes
perfectly and everything is wonderful,

371
00:20:21.327 --> 00:20:25.038
and I gave you a perfect example, right?
>> Right.

372
00:20:25.038 --> 00:20:26.982
>> We didn't have any warnings,

373
00:20:26.982 --> 00:20:28.410
nothing barked at us.

374
00:20:28.410 --> 00:20:30.100
Everything was in the same place.

375
00:20:31.330 --> 00:20:33.030
I do have a part two running.
>> Yeah?

376
00:20:33.030 --> 00:20:34.050
>> Because I wanted to go ahead and

377
00:20:34.050 --> 00:20:34.630
show you, yeah.

378
00:20:34.630 --> 00:20:36.330
This is the basics of it.

379
00:20:36.330 --> 00:20:41.630
I wanna drive a little bit into the things
with the styles and how that works,

380
00:20:41.630 --> 00:20:45.980
and when things might not always
go perfectly smooth for you.

381
00:20:45.980 --> 00:20:49.468
So we have a part two coming
your way in just a little bit.

382
00:20:49.468 --> 00:20:50.640
>> All right, Vonne, well thank you for

383
00:20:50.640 --> 00:20:54.060
helping us to get started here
with the use of master documents.

384
00:20:54.060 --> 00:20:56.440
And you're starting to see
where it becomes very powerful,

385
00:20:56.440 --> 00:20:59.265
especially when you think about
the idea of collaborating.

386
00:20:59.265 --> 00:21:02.930
Sso we gave you a couple of great examples
there, where it might be one person really

387
00:21:02.930 --> 00:21:06.810
collating everything together, needing to
put things into the order that they need

388
00:21:06.810 --> 00:21:10.900
to, and showing where we can even leave
that open for editing using subdocument

389
00:21:10.900 --> 00:21:13.960
features that we have available
while I was renumbering the pages.

390
00:21:13.960 --> 00:21:16.350
And now we have to manage

391
00:21:16.350 --> 00:21:19.577
Because even though it actually looks

392
00:21:19.577 --> 00:21:21.455
we might find out that's
there more to come and

393
00:21:21.455 --> 00:21:23.351
that we have to actually
do some other things.

394
00:21:23.351 --> 00:21:25.464
But that is gonna for part two.

395
00:21:25.464 --> 00:21:27.883
So let's go ahead and
end this episode then.

396
00:21:27.883 --> 00:21:31.899
Signing off for OfficePro TV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

397
00:21:31.899 --> 00:21:32.811

398
00:21:32.811 --> 00:21:34.306
>> Stay tuned right here for

00:21:34.306 --> 00:21:37.087

episodes.description: Vonne and Ronnie discuss some of the issues one might encounter when using master documents.  They demonstrate issues with mismatched styles, common warning prompts, and linking issues.

And I emphasized in the last

>> Right.
>> You have to have headings and

And that's so very important
because of the outline mode and

And yes, that's great.

Wonderful if everybody goes ahead and

In the sense of like different elements

But you have to have very specific

38

39
00:01:47.785 --> 00:01:48.890
[LAUGH]

So I wanna do a quick little

And that could or could not, depends which

But it is something that does happen with

00:02:08.680 --> 00:02:14.280

Best to just go ahead and demonstrate.

00:02:15.950 --> 00:02:18.340
Cuz you're just going mm-hm, what?

Okay.

48
00:02:18.976 --> 00:02:22.514
[LAUGH] That's Ronnie,
Ronnie's face is doing that by the way so.

49
00:02:22.514 --> 00:02:23.370
>> It always is.

50
00:02:23.370 --> 00:02:27.593
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

51
00:02:27.593 --> 00:02:29.785
>> Yeah, it's usually when I'm talking to,

00:02:29.785 --> 00:02:32.167
that he's like mm-hm, yeah, sure, Vonne.

53
00:02:32.167 --> 00:02:34.039
[LAUGH]
>> That's good that I'm learning

54
00:02:34.039 --> 00:02:35.075

55
00:02:35.075 --> 00:02:36.360
All right, so Vonne, here we go.

56
00:02:36.360 --> 00:02:39.280
We're really trying to deal with the very
fact that we're going to have all these

00:02:39.280 --> 00:02:40.640

58
00:02:40.640 --> 00:02:45.170
And they can be, again,
people tend to like their own style.

59
00:02:45.170 --> 00:02:46.360
They don't care what you tell them.

60
00:02:46.360 --> 00:02:51.050
If it's saying, hey, we're gonna merge
this altogether, so keep it to a minimum.

61
00:02:51.050 --> 00:02:53.210
All of a sudden,
you get some that are just way out there.

62
00:02:53.210 --> 00:02:55.080
And you're not exactly sure what happened.

63
00:02:55.080 --> 00:02:57.440
Vonne is talking about that
idea of inconsistencies.

64
00:02:57.440 --> 00:03:00.740
And Vonne, we've even seen as you
go around on the Internet, right?

65
00:03:00.740 --> 00:03:04.040
Some of the different articles or
blogs that are out there,

00:03:04.040 --> 00:03:07.870
it can get a little bit dicey when

67
00:03:07.870 --> 00:03:10.524

68
00:03:10.524 --> 00:03:12.035
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

69
00:03:12.035 --> 00:03:12.893
>> Let's stick with styles.

70
00:03:12.893 --> 00:03:13.394
>> Right.
>> And

71
00:03:13.394 --> 00:03:16.838
then we'll get into the really bad things.

72
00:03:16.838 --> 00:03:17.676
[LAUGH]
>> Right.

73
00:03:17.676 --> 00:03:20.045
[LAUGH]
>> So let's jump down here and

00:03:20.045 --> 00:03:24.550
we have the document that I've
created in the first part of this

00:03:24.550 --> 00:03:28.040
little miniseries of master documents.

76
00:03:28.040 --> 00:03:31.962
Everything worked wonderfully, because,
now these were all created on a PC.

77
00:03:31.962 --> 00:03:34.460
So and I brought them over and
I'm using them on my Mac.

78
00:03:34.460 --> 00:03:37.690
And so when I look at these things,
and these are the same copied files.

79
00:03:37.690 --> 00:03:41.420
So this is a continuation from the last
show where I made another heading,

00:03:41.420 --> 00:03:43.680
I made some things red,
so on and so forth.

81
00:03:43.680 --> 00:03:48.300
But this is using Heading 1,

82
00:03:48.300 --> 00:03:53.618
In the master document, we're using
the exact same Heading 1s and Heading 2s.

83
00:03:53.618 --> 00:03:56.030
And you're like, well,
don't all of them use Heading 1s?

84
00:03:56.030 --> 00:03:58.170
And all the Heading 1s are the same.

85
00:03:58.170 --> 00:04:03.510
Well, when you go from PC to Mac,
their styles are different, okay?

86
00:04:03.510 --> 00:04:05.354
Watch what's gonna happen.

87
00:04:05.354 --> 00:04:08.106
Sorry, let me just double-check,

88
00:04:08.106 --> 00:04:10.915
This is just a normal Heading 1.

89
00:04:10.915 --> 00:04:13.228
This is just a normal Heading 2.

90
00:04:13.228 --> 00:04:16.220
This is just a normal normal [LAUGH] file.

91
00:04:16.220 --> 00:04:18.021
>> [LAUGH]
>> Everything's great.

92
00:04:18.021 --> 00:04:20.320
Yeah, that's some red there,

93
00:04:21.850 --> 00:04:24.790
I'm going to start a new file,
by the way, I'm doing Cmd+W, sorry,

94
00:04:24.790 --> 00:04:26.390
I'm using my shortcuts a lot.

95
00:04:27.680 --> 00:04:31.300
I'm going to create a brand

of all the things we use especially
things like master documents.

328

So thank you again, Vonne, and
also thank you for watching.

329
00:16:44.710 --> 00:16:47.070
But that's gonna end it for this episode.

00:16:47.070 --> 00:16:50.490
Signing off for OfficeProTV,
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

331
00:16:50.490 --> 00:16:51.460
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

332
00:16:51.460 --> 00:16:55.371
>> Stay tuned right here for
the Word 2016 Expert for Mac show.

333
00:16:55.371 --> 00:17:00.169
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne show you how to track changes made to documents in Word 2016 for Mac. Here you will specifically learn how to enable/disable tracking, add comments, make changes, and how to modify display preferences. They demonstrate how to review tracked changes by accepting or rejecting changes as well as deleting comments. They also show how to lock tracking so collaborators cannot turn them off.
episodes.title: Track Changes
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

With the track changes on, I can,

00:09:46.672 --> 00:09:50.900
I'm gonna zoom out just a little bit

00:09:50.900 --> 00:09:52.150

00:09:52.150 --> 00:09:56.313
Depending on your settings,
get that in a minute, it went ahead and

There's also, on the left-hand side,

218

Tracking changes are gonna be very

There's a lot of great features in here

00:28:09.858 --> 00:28:12.466

00:28:12.466 --> 00:28:17.958

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne take a look at two separate, yet related functions – compare documents and combine documents. First, they explore using compare documents which allows you to merge two documents together and Word highlights the differences. Next, they show you how to combine tracked edits from multiple documents into a single document.
episodes.title: Compare and Combine Documents

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne show you how to collaborate with others to make edits in your documents using OneDrive and other Office 365 account features. They will explain how to invite collaborators, chat in real time, and remove sharing in OneDrive when necessary. They demonstrate using both locally installed Word and Word Online.
episodes.title: Collaborate Online

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne go over some important security features found in Word for Mac. Specific features you'll see here includes, hidden text, restrict editing, and adding password protection to a document. They also discuss the differences between options offered in Word for Mac versus Word for Windows.

00:27:24.470 --> 00:27:27.260
And in a very simple way,

it's just verifying that I am

578
00:27:31.750 --> 00:27:34.800
when you receive it you know that it

00:27:34.800 --> 00:27:36.724

00:27:41.810 --> 00:27:47.130
The very fact is, if Vonne is putting that

583
00:27:47.130 --> 00:27:51.500

00:27:51.500 --> 00:27:53.850
That Vonne didn't intend
to put in there and

585
00:27:53.850 --> 00:27:57.150
I read it and
not understand what's happened.

586
00:27:57.150 --> 00:27:59.800
A digital signature works
in a couple of ways.

587
00:27:59.800 --> 00:28:01.650
One, it verifies the origin.

588
00:28:01.650 --> 00:28:03.440
On other words, it came from Vonne.

589
00:28:03.440 --> 00:28:06.830
Secondly though,
it makes this mark on the file.

590
00:28:06.830 --> 00:28:10.500
It generates a mathematical process and
puts an answer on it.

591
00:28:10.500 --> 00:28:13.120
And then when my computer
opens it up it goes, look,

592
00:28:13.120 --> 00:28:19.020
the hash that's on that file is different
than what is reporting when I open it up.

593
00:28:19.020 --> 00:28:22.010
Which means that somewhere along the line
somebody has messed around with that

594
00:28:22.010 --> 00:28:22.930
document.

595
00:28:22.930 --> 00:28:25.800
And that's what prevents
you from actually getting

596
00:28:25.800 --> 00:28:28.210
unusual information
that you shouldn't get.

597
00:28:28.210 --> 00:28:31.130
It really does help identify and
helps to protect

598
00:28:31.130 --> 00:28:35.530
the idea that the information is the same
as when it left Vonne's computer.

599
00:28:35.530 --> 00:28:39.622
Same when I read it on my computer.
>> And to just clarify,

600
00:28:39.622 --> 00:28:41.924
a hash is kinda like an ID code.

601
00:28:41.924 --> 00:28:46.323
A unique ID code that is
generated in that instance and

602
00:28:46.323 --> 00:28:49.880
then those hashes are compared.

603
00:28:49.880 --> 00:28:51.770
I always call it the secret handshake.

604
00:28:51.770 --> 00:28:55.482
If you're getting into your organization
you have to do the [SOUND].

605
00:28:55.482 --> 00:28:56.550
>> Yeah.

606
00:28:56.550 --> 00:28:57.410
>> And if you don't do it in the right

607
00:28:57.410 --> 00:28:59.790
sequence, then I know
that you don't know it.

00:28:59.790 --> 00:29:04.917
So there's this whole sending,
if I'm trying to verify my authenticity

00:29:04.917 --> 00:29:10.141

00:29:10.141 --> 00:29:13.130
So now he has something to judge

00:29:13.130 --> 00:29:19.511

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne demonstrate working with document properties which will help make a document more searchable as well as adding more usable information to a document. This is also known as metadata. They also discuss the importance of checking for accessibility in documents.

episodes.description: Justin and Vonne demonstrate how to create fillable forms in Word for Mac.  They show how to insert text fields, checkboxes, and dropdown menus. They also discuss the importance of the protect forms command to allow users to use to form.
episodes.title: Forms
